title-group.article-title: Role of Peltigera rufescens (Weis) Humb. (a lichen) on imazalil-induced genotoxicity: analysis of micronucleus and chromosome aberrations in vitro

contrib-group.aff: Department of Biology, Atatürk University, Erzurum, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Elanur Aydın, Department of Biology, Atatürk University, Erzurum 25240, Turkey. Email: elanuraydinn@gmail.com

abstract.p: Imazalil (IMA), a commonly used fungicide in both agricultural and clinical domains, is suspected to produce very serious toxic effects on vertebrates. On the other hand, in recent years, a number of studies have suggested that lichens might be easily accessible sources of natural drugs that could be used as a possible food supplement. Extensive research is being carried out to explore the importance of lichen species, which are known to contain a variety of pharmacological active compounds. In this context, the anti-genotoxic effects of aqueous Peltigera rufescens (Weis) Humb. extracts (PREs) were studied against the genotoxic damage induced by IMA on cultured human lymphocytes using chromosomal aberrations (CAs) and micronucleus (MN) as cytogenetic parameters. Human peripheral lymphocytes were treated in vitro with varying concentrations of PREs (0, 5, 10, 25, 50 and 100 mg/L), tested in combination with IMA (336 mg/L). PREs alone were not genotoxic and when combined with IMA treatment, reduced the frequency of CAs and the rates of MNs. A clear dose-dependent decrease in the genotoxic damage of IMA was observed, suggesting a genoprotective role of P. rufescens extract. The results of the present study indicate that this plant extract per se do not have genotoxic potential but can minimize the genotoxicity of IMA on human lymphocytes in vitro. In conclusion our findings may have an important application for the protection of human lymphocyte from the genetic damage and side effects induced by agricultural and medical chemicals hazardous in people.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Imazalil (C14H14Cl2N2O; IMA) is a fungicide that is used extensively in fruit plantations and post-harvest treatments but has teratogenic effects on vertebrate development (Zega et al., 2009). IMA is suspected to produce craniofacial malformations in vertebrates and scarce data are available about its genotoxicity. The only two investigations on IMA genotoxicity clearly indicated that the fungicide induced significant DNA damage in a dose-dependent manner (Vindas et al., 2004; Sişman and Türkez, 2010). Again, toxicity tests on sperm viability, fertilization and embryogenesis of the solitary ascidian Phallusia mammillata were performed to evaluate the effects of IMA. According to the results of this study, fertilization rate significantly decreased after 30-min exposure of sperm to 25 µM IMA and after exposure of both gametes to 50 µM IMA as compared to controls (Pennati et al., 2006). It was also reported that IMA produced some adverse effects in reproductive and neurobehavioral parameters in mice (Tanaka, 1995). In brief, the contemporaneous exposure to IMA or its therapeutic use was considered potentially dangerous for human conspectuses (Menegola et al., 2006).

Lichens are symbiotic microorganisms that consist of algae and fungi (Nash, 1996). Lichens were used as raw material in paint and cosmetic industry, environmental indicators, food and medicine for various purposes (Cocchietto et al., 2002; Dilsizoğlu et al., 2004; Yazıcı and Aslan, 2006). Biological activities and chemical composition of lichens have long been investigated for antimicrobial (Candan et al., 2007), antiviral (Fazio et al., 2007), antitumoral (Rezanka and Dembitsky, 2006), antiproliferative (Ren et al., 2009), anti-inflammatory (Süleyman et al., 2003), insecticidal (Çetin et al., 2008), antimutagenic (Türkez et al., 2010; Türkez and Dirican, 2011) and antioxidant (Kohlhardt-Floehr et al., 2010) properties till today.

In last years, many efforts are being made to investigate therapeutic substances that are capable of reducing the genotoxicity of various natural and man-made mutagens in human life. These include vitamins, sulfhydryl substances, minerals, algal and plant products (Edenharder et al., 1999; Rao et al., 2001; Türkez, 2011; Türkez and Şişman, 2007; Türkez and Geyikoglu, 2010; Türkez et al., 2010a, b, 2011;). Concomitant treatment with the antioxidants with mutagens provided protection against oxidative damage in experimental animals (Abubakar et al., 2003; Esparza et al., 2003; Türkez and Geyikoglu, 2010). As a matter of fact, Halici et al. (2005) reported that, the water extract of Usnea longissima has a protective effect on indomethacin-induced tissue damage, which can be attributed to its antioxidant potential. To our best knowledge, there is no recorded data on the role of Peltigera rufescens (Weis) Humb. extracts (PREs) against IMA-induced cytogenetic damage in human lymphocytes in the literature. Therefore, the aim of the present study was to assess the potential beneficial role of PREs on IMA-induced genotoxicity. For this aim, we assessed the frequencies of chromosome aberrations (CAs) and micronuclei (MNs) in cultured human lymphocytes following treatments with PREs and IMA using two different cytogenetic end points. CA and MN are inexpensive, very rapid and sensitive tests for evaluating the presence and extent of DNA damage in human populations that are exposed to mutagenic and or carcinogenic substances in their environments and lifestyles.

sec.title: Plants
sec.p: Peltigera rufescens was collected from the Erzurum and Artvin provinces during August 2010. After drying at the room temperature, a stereo microscope, a compound microscope, and the usual spot tests were used in the identification of the samples with the reference books (Aslan and Yazici, 2006; Poelt, 1974; Purvis et al., 1992; Wirth, 1995). The specimens are stored in the herbarium of Kazım Karabekir, Faculty of Education, Atatürk University, Erzurum.

sec.title: Extraction
sec.p: For water extraction of PRE, 20 g of sample was mixed with 400 ml distillated and boiling water using magnetic stirrer for 15 min. Then the extracts were filtered over Whatmann No. 1 paper.

sec.title: Experimental design
sec.p: The heparinized blood samples from five healthy nonsmoking donors between the ages 27 and 28 with no history of exposure to any genotoxic agent were used in our experiments. Questionnaires were obtained for each blood donor to evaluate exposure history, and in addition, informed consent forms were signed by each donor. In all the volunteers involved in this study, hematological and biochemical parameters were analyzed and no pathology was detected. The fungicide IMA (1-[2-(2,4-dichlorophenyl)-2-(2-propenyloxy) ethyl]-1H-imidazole sulfate, CAS No. 58594-72-2) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich® (St Louis, MO, USA). IMA (at 336 mg/L and dissolved in DMSO) and various concentrations (0, 5, 10, 25, 50 and 100 mg/L) of aqueous extracts of lichen were tested in cultured human lymphocytes. These compounds were added to the cultures just before incubation for cytogenetic analysis. Experiments were conformed to the guidelines of the World Medical Assembly (Declaration of Helsinki). The concentrations were selected according to the previous reports (Aydin, 2011; Sisman and Türkez, 2010; Vindas et al., 2004). After supplementation of IMA and PREs, the blood was incubated for 72 h at 37°C to adjust body conditions for testing CAs and MN. Each individual whole blood culture without IMA or PRE was studied as a control group.

sec.title: CA assay
sec.p: Human peripheral blood lymphocyte cultures were set up according to a slight modification of the protocol described by Evans and O’Riordan (1975). A 0.5-ml aliquot of heparinized blood was cultured in 6 ml of culture medium (Chromosome Medium B; Biochrom, Berlin) with 5 mg/mL of phytohemagglutinin (Biochrom). The cultures were incubated in complete darkness for 72 h at 37°C. Two hours prior to harvesting, 0.1 ml of colchicine (0.2 mg/mL) (Sigma-Aldrich®, St-Louis, MO, USA) was added to the culture flask. Hypotonic treatment and fixation were performed. To prepare slides, 3–5 drops of the fixed cell suspension were dropped on a clean slide and air-dried. The slides were stained in 3% Giemsa solution in phosphate buffer (pH 6.8) for 15 min. For each treatment, 25 well-spread metaphases were analyzed to detect the presence of CAs. Criteria to classify the different types of aberrations (chromatid or chromosome gap and chromatid or chromosome break) were in accordance with the recommendation of EHC (Environmental Health Criteria) 46 for environmental monitoring of human populations (IPCS, 1985).

sec.title: MN assay
sec.p: The MN test was performed by adding cytochalasin B (Sigma-Aldrich®, St-Louis, MO, USA) after 44 h of culture as previously described by Fenech and Morley (1985). At the end of the incubation period, the lymphocytes were fixed with ice-cold methanol:acetic acid (1:1). The fixed cells were put directly on slides using a cytospin and stained with May Grünwald-Giemsa. All slides were coded before scoring. The slides were scored according to criteria reported by Fenech (1993). At least 2000 binucleated lymphocytes were examined per concentration (two cultures per concentration) for the presence of one, two or more MNs.

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: The results are expressed as mean ± standard deviation (SD). Comparisons between groups were carried out by one-way analysis of variance followed by Duncan multiple range test with the level of significance set at p < 0.05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The unprotected cultures treated with IMA showed significant increases in the CA frequencies (p < 0.05). On the contrary, the PRE doses alone (5, 10, 25, 50 and 100 μg/ml) also did not change the frequencies of CAs. However, high statistical significances in the reduction of CA frequencies were found in the cultures concomitantly treated with PREs and IMA as compared to the group treated with MA alone (Figure 1 ).

caption.p: Results of chromosomal aberration (CA) assay in human lymphocytes treated with Peltigera rufescens extracts (0, 5, 10, 25, 50 and 100 mg/L), imazalil (336 mg/L) and their combinations. (Each value represents mean ± SD of five experiments; means in the figure followed by the different letters present significant differences at the p < 0.05 level. PRE1: 5 mg/L P. rufescens water extract; PRE2: 10 mg/L P. rufescens water extract; PRE3: 25 mg/L P. rufescens water extract; PRE4: 50 mg/L P. rufescens water extract; PRE5: 100 mg/L P. rufescens water extract; IMA: 336 mg/L imazalil).

sec.p: In the treatment for 72 h a significant increase in induced MN was found at 336 mg/L of IMA (p < 0.05). PRE at all tested concentrations did not increase the rate of MNs (data not shown). However, the positive effect of PRE in decreasing the incidence of MNs in comparison with an unprotected level was attained when cultures were treated simultaneously with IMA and PRE (Figure 2 ).

caption.p: Results of micronucleus (MN) assay in human lymphocytes treated with Peltigera rufescens extracts (0, 5, 10, 25, 50 and 100 mg/L), imazalil (336 mg/L) and their combinations. Abbreviations are as same as given in Figure 1.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The mutagenic and clastogenic chemicals cause teratogenic and/or carcinogenic effects (Babich et al., 1985). The results of this study indicated that IMA caused DNA damages in lymphocytes, because dose-dependent increases of MN and CA frequencies were observed in IMA-treated cultures. In fact, CA test is regarded as a very important and useful indicator of exposure to biological and chemical agents (Padovani et al., 1997). MN assay provides a measure of both chromosome breakage and chromosome loss or non-disjunction in clastogenic and aneugenic events, respectively (Karaman et al., 2009). And damaged DNA can lead to aneuploidy and/or chromosomal instability, which is believed to be a major contributor to tumor progression (Erol, 2010). This finding is supported by other investigators. As a matter of fact, Vindas et al. (2004) detected DNA single-strand breaks and alkali-labile sites by comet assay in cultured human lymphocytes and reported that IMA caused DNA damage. IMA-induced genotoxicity in humans was also reported by Ramirez and Cuenca (2002). Likewise, IMA caused increases of the frequencies of the CAs and the rates of MN as compared to controls in a dose-dependent manner (Sisman and Türkez, 2010). However, there are also contradictory findings on mutagenicity of IMA (Thienpont et al., 1981).

Nakagawa and Moore (1995) found that addition of IMA to the suspensions of isolated rat hepatocytes caused cell death accompanied by depletion of intracellular glutathione (GSH) and protein thiols, with accumulation of intracellular malondialdehyde (MDA). So the genotoxic effects of IMA that were observed in this study could be explained in relation with its oxidative damage potential. At this point, we suggest that PREs could have important biological and pharmaceutical consequences, because IMA induced CA and MN formations in our study were also alleviated by concurrent administration of PREs. There are multiple forms of superoxide dismutase (SOD) and catalase (CAT) in lichens (Weissman et al., 2006). However, any report concerning the roles on the cellular activities of these enzymes is not available in literature. However, antioxidant enzymes (especially, SOD and CAT) play a main role in the defense mechanism of mammalian blood and other tissues (Prasad et al., 2006). It was indicated that the water extracts of lichens present important effects against tissue damages, which can be attributed to their antioxidant potential (Halici et al., 2005). PREs were reported to have no lichen substances (Brodo et al., 2001). However, the food value of Peltigera canina, as well as its use in treating several disorders such as liver complaints, could be due to its high protein and essential amino acid content, of which the free methionine content could be the most significant (Subramanian and Ramakrishnan, 1964). The amino acid methionine is known to exert antioxidant effects by as yet unidentified mechanisms but the amino acid contains sulfur which is needed for producing GSH, the most profuse antioxidant in the body (Erdmann et al., 2005).

In conclusion, the most probable mechanism of DNA damage and chromosome breakage by IMA seems to be through the oxidative stress. And the present investigation indicates that P. rufescens water extract have a genoprotective effect on IMA-induced genotoxic damage. This finding can have an important application for the protection of human lymphocytes from the genotoxic damages induced by agricultural chemicals hazardous to people.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
